Federated Learning for Non-factorizable Models using Deep Generative Prior Approximations

Conor Hassan111conorhassan.ai@gmail.com 1,2, Joshua J. Bon 3, Elizaveta Semenova 4,
Antonietta Mira 5,6, Kerrie Mengersen 1,2
1 Centre for Data Science, Queensland University of Technology
2 School of Mathematical Sciences, Queensland University of Technology
3 CEREMADE, UniversitÃ© Paris-Dauphine
4 Imperial College London
5 Euler Institute, UniversitÃ  della Svizzera italiana (USI)
6 Insubria University
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) allows for collaborative model training across decentralized clients while preserving privacy by avoiding data sharing. However, current FL methods assume conditional independence between client models, limiting the use of priors that capture dependence, such as Gaussian processes (GPs).Â We introduce the Structured Independence via deep Generative Model Approximation (SIGMA) prior which enables FL for non-factorizable models across clients, expanding the applicability of FL to fields such as spatial statistics, epidemiology, environmental science, and other domains where modeling dependencies is crucial. The SIGMA prior is a pre-trained deep generative model that approximates the desired prior and induces a specified conditional independence structure in the latent variables, creating an approximate model suitable for FL settings. We demonstrate the SIGMA priorâ€™s effectiveness on synthetic data and showcase its utility in a real-world example of FL for spatial data, using a conditional autoregressive prior to model spatial dependence across Australia. Our work enables new FL applications in domains where modeling dependent data is essential for accurate predictions and decision-making.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative model estimation across multiple clients without needing centralized data aggregation (McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017; Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2021). FL addresses critical data privacy, security, and ownership concerns by enabling model training on decentralized data. However, a fundamental limitation of current FL algorithms is the assumption of strict conditional independence between the data from different clients (Kotelevskii etÂ al.,, 2022; Hassan etÂ al.,, 2023). This assumption implies that the local parameters of each client are independent given the global parameters, but this is often not true in real-world settings, such as spatio-temporal modeling or graph-structured data, where observations across clients exhibit complex dependencies. As a result, applying FL to these domains requires additional, suboptimal assumptions that limit the effectiveness and accuracy of the learned models.

To address this challenge, we introduce Structured Independence via deep Generative Model Approximation (SIGMA) priors, a novel approach to enabling scalable FL algorithms for models with dependent data. The key idea is to train a hierarchical variational autoencoder (VAE) to approximate the prior distribution over client-specific parameters. The SIGMA prior learns a latent representation that captures dependencies between clients while providing a conditionally-independent structure, enabling the use of existing efficient FL algorithms.

We consider probabilistic models of the form

Ï•bold-italic-Ï•\displaystyle\bm{\phi} âˆ¼pâ€‹(Ï•),similar-toabsentğ‘bold-italic-Ï•\displaystyle\sim p(\bm{\phi}), (1)
ğœ½j|ğœ½âˆ’j,Ï•conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•\displaystyle\bm{\theta}_{j}|\bm{\theta}_{-j},\bm{\phi} âˆ¼pâ€‹(ğœ½j|ğœ½âˆ’j,Ï•),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J},formulae-sequencesimilar-toabsentğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘—1â€¦ğ½\displaystyle\sim p(\bm{\theta}_{j}|\bm{\theta}_{{-j}},\bm{\phi}),\hskip 8.5359ptj\in\{1,\ldots,J\}, (2)
ğ’šj|ğœ½j,Ï•conditionalsubscriptğ’šğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•\displaystyle\bm{y}_{j}|\bm{\theta}_{j},\bm{\phi} âˆ¼indpâ€‹(ğ’šj|ğœ½j,Ï•),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J},formulae-sequencesuperscriptsimilar-toindabsentğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ’šğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘—1â€¦ğ½\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm ind}}{{\sim}}p(\bm{y}_{j}|\bm{\theta}_{j},\bm{\phi}),\quad j\in\{1,\ldots,J\}, (3)

where Ï•bold-italic-Ï•\bm{\phi} are global parameters shared across all Jğ½J clients, ğœ½jsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—\bm{\theta}_{j} are local parameters specific to client jğ‘—j, ğœ½âˆ’jsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—\bm{\theta}_{{-j}} denotes local parameters from all clients except jğ‘—j, and ğ’šjsubscriptğ’šğ‘—\bm{y}_{j} is the data available to client jğ‘—j. Existing FL algorithms, such as structured federated variational inference (SFVI, Hassan etÂ al.,, 2023) and FedSOUL (Kotelevskii etÂ al.,, 2022), restrict (2) with a local conditional independence property, that is,

pâ€‹(ğœ½j|ğœ½âˆ’j,Ï•)=pâ€‹(ğœ½j|Ï•),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J}.formulae-sequenceğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘—1â€¦ğ½\displaystyle p(\bm{\theta}_{j}|\bm{\theta}_{-j},\bm{\phi})=p(\bm{\theta}_{j}|\bm{\phi}),\quad j\in\{1,\ldots,J\}. (4)

However, prior densities that do not satisfy (4) are common in statistics and machine learning. For example, Markov random field (MRF, Besag etÂ al.,, 1991; Rue etÂ al.,, 2009) and Gaussian process (GP) priors (Bernardo etÂ al.,, 1998; Williams and Rasmussen,, 2006) are a common choice to capture spatial and temporal dependence between observations in applications such as image inpainting (ruv,, 2014), disease mapping (Lee,, 2011; Riebler etÂ al.,, 2016), and graph neural networks (Hasanzadeh etÂ al.,, 2020).

Figure 1 illustrates the challenge of applying such priors in a federated setting. The left panel shows the standard dependency structure for a conditional autoregressive (CAR) prior in a non-FL setting. In the FL setting (right panel), the bold borders represent boundaries between clients, and the red grids indicate values that cannot be evaluated when inferring the value at the dark-green grids due to the lack of access to data from other clients.

Our work aims to address this challenge by developing a novel approach that can capture the dependencies among local parameters while still enabling efficient and privacy-preserving learning in the FL setting. The SIGMA prior enables the use of computationally scalable FL algorithms for models with assumed dependencies between observations captured by the prior structure.

The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 provides background on the model class of interest, SFVI, and VAEs. Section 3 introduces the SIGMA prior and our proposed methodology. Section 4 presents the results of our experiments on synthetic and real-world applications. Finally, Section 5 concludes the paper with a discussion of the limitations and future directions for this work.

2.1 Structured Federated Variational Inference

Variational inference (VI, Blei etÂ al.,, 2017; Zhang etÂ al.,, 2018) is an algorithmic technique that approximates the posterior distribution pâ€‹(ğœ½|ğ’š)ğ‘conditionalğœ½ğ’šp(\bm{\theta}|\bm{y}), which is often intractable for analytical or direct computation due to the complexity of the model. The key idea of VI is to introduce a parameterized distribution qğ€â€‹(ğœ½)âˆˆğ’¬subscriptğ‘ğ€ğœ½ğ’¬q_{\bm{\lambda}}(\bm{\theta})\in\mathcal{Q} called the variational approximation, that aims to approximate the posterior distribution. The variational parameters ğ€ğ€\bm{\lambda} are optimized to find the best approximation from a fixed variational family of distributions, ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}.

The objective in the VI framework is to maximize the evidence lower bound (ELBO), defined as:

â„’â€‹(ğ€):=ğ”¼ğœ½âˆ¼qğ€â€‹[logâ¡pâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ’š)âˆ’logâ¡qğ€â€‹(ğœ½)],assignâ„’ğ€subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ½subscriptğ‘ğ€delimited-[]ğ‘ğœ½ğ’šsubscriptğ‘ğ€ğœ½\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\bm{\lambda}):=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\theta}\sim q_{\bm{\lambda}}}[\log p(\bm{\theta},\bm{y})-\log q_{\bm{\lambda}}(\bm{\theta})], (5)

which acts as a surrogate objective function, providing a lower bound to the log marginal likelihood. Maximizing the ELBO is equivalent to minimizing the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between the variational approximation qğ€â€‹(ğœ½)subscriptğ‘ğ€ğœ½q_{\bm{\lambda}}(\bm{\theta}) and the posterior distribution pâ€‹(ğœ½|ğ’š)ğ‘conditionalğœ½ğ’šp(\bm{\theta}|\bm{y}). When the variational approximation matches the true posterior, the ELBO equals the log marginal likelihood.

Gradient-based optimization algorithms (Ruder,, 2017) are commonly used to maximize the ELBO, relying on unbiased gradient estimators. A significant advancement in stochastic VI (Hoffman etÂ al.,, 2013) is the reparameterization gradient estimator (Titsias and LÃ¡zaro-Gredilla,, 2014; Kingma and Welling,, 2013; Rezende etÂ al.,, 2014), which allows for an efficient and low-variance estimate of the ELBO. The key idea is to express a sample of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} drawn from qğ€â€‹(ğœ½)subscriptğ‘ğ€ğœ½q_{\bm{\lambda}}(\bm{\theta}) as a deterministic function of ğ€ğ€\bm{\lambda} by transforming random noise Ïµbold-italic-Ïµ\bm{\epsilon}: ğœ½=fğ€â€‹(Ïµ)ğœ½subscriptğ‘“ğ€bold-italic-Ïµ\bm{\theta}=f_{\bm{\lambda}}(\bm{\epsilon}). The noise variable Ïµbold-italic-Ïµ\bm{\epsilon} is drawn from a distribution qÏµsubscriptğ‘bold-italic-Ïµq_{\bm{\epsilon}}, which is independent of ğ€ğ€\bm{\lambda}. This reparameterization enables the computation of low-variance gradients, which is crucial for efficient optimization in VI. A resulting single-sample unbiased Monte Carlo estimator of the desired gradient vector is the sticking-the-landing (STL) estimator (Roeder etÂ al.,, 2017),

âˆ‡^ğ€â€‹â„’:=âˆ‚fğ€â€‹(Ïµ)âˆ‚ğ€âŠ¤â€‹âˆ‡ğœ½[logâ¡pâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ’š)âˆ’logâ¡qğ€â€‹(ğœ½)].assignsubscript^âˆ‡ğ€â„’superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ€bold-italic-Ïµğ€topsubscriptâˆ‡ğœ½ğ‘ğœ½ğ’šsubscriptğ‘ğ€ğœ½\displaystyle\widehat{\nabla}_{\bm{\lambda}}\mathcal{L}:={\frac{\partial f_{\bm{\lambda}}(\bm{\epsilon})}{\partial\bm{\lambda}}}^{\top}\nabla_{\bm{\theta}}[\log p(\bm{\theta},\bm{y})-\log q_{\bm{\lambda}}(\bm{\theta})]. (6)

Structured federated variational inference (SFVI, Hassan etÂ al.,, 2023) extends VI to the FL setting, focusing on hierarchical Bayesian models of the form,

pâ€‹(ğ’š,Ï•,ğœ½)=pâ€‹(Ï•)â€‹âˆj=1Jpâ€‹(ğœ½j|Ï•)â€‹pâ€‹(ğ’šj|ğœ½j,Ï•).ğ‘ğ’šbold-italic-Ï•ğœ½ğ‘bold-italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘—1ğ½ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘conditionalsubscriptğ’šğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•\displaystyle p(\bm{y},\bm{\phi},\bm{\theta})=p(\bm{\phi})\prod_{j=1}^{J}p(\bm{\theta}_{j}|\bm{\phi})p(\bm{y}_{j}|\bm{\theta}_{j},\bm{\phi}).

where the local parameters ğœ½jsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—\bm{\theta}_{j} only appear in the likelihood component for the jğ‘—j-th client, and the sets of local parameters are assumed to be conditionally independent given the global parameters. To enable efficient and privacy-preserving learning in the federated setting, SFVI employs a factorized structured variational approximation (Hoffman and Blei,, 2015; Ranganath etÂ al.,, 2016; Tan etÂ al.,, 2020) of the form:

qâ€‹(Ï•,ğœ½)=qğ‹Gâ€‹(Ï•)â€‹âˆj=1Jqğ‹Ljâ€‹(ğœ½j|Ï•),ğ‘bold-italic-Ï•ğœ½subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‹ğºbold-italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘—1ğ½subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‹subscriptğ¿ğ‘—conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•\displaystyle q(\bm{\phi},\bm{\theta})=q_{\bm{\varphi}_{G}}(\bm{\phi})\prod_{j=1}^{J}q_{\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}}}(\bm{\theta}_{j}|\bm{\phi}),

where qğ‹Gâ€‹(Ï•)subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‹ğºbold-italic-Ï•q_{\bm{\varphi}_{G}}(\bm{\phi}) is a Gaussian distribution parameterized by ğ‹Gsubscriptğ‹ğº\bm{\varphi}_{G}, and each qğ‹Ljâ€‹(ğœ½j|Ï•)subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‹subscriptğ¿ğ‘—conditionalsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—bold-italic-Ï•q_{\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}}}(\bm{\theta}_{j}|\bm{\phi}) is a Gaussian distribution parameterized by ğ‹Ljsubscriptğ‹subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}}, potentially including dependencies on Ï•bold-italic-Ï•\bm{\phi}. This factorization allows for local optimization and privacy-preserving updates, as the local variational parameters ğ‹Ljsubscriptğ‹subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}} can be updated independently by each client without sharing them with the server. SFVI leverages the factorized structure of the variational approximation to decompose the ELBO into a sum of local ELBOs, each of which can be optimized locally by a client. Two algorithms, SFVI and SFVI-Avg, are derived for combinations of models and variational approximations that share this form. Both algorithms enable parallel and private updates of the local variational parameters ğ‹Ljsubscriptğ‹subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}} for each client, requiring only the communication of gradient information concerning the global variational parameters ğ‹Gsubscriptğ‹ğº\bm{\varphi}_{G} to the server at each iteration.

In the numerical examples presented in this work, we focus on the SFVI algorithm, as it returns the exact estimates that fit the equivalent variational approximation on the full dataset in the non-FL setting. While SFVI provides a principled and efficient approach to learning hierarchical Bayesian models in federated settings, it assumes that the local parameters are conditionally independent given the global parameters. This assumption may limit the applicability of SFVI to models with dependent local parameters, which are common in real-world applications. In Section 3, we introduce the SIGMA prior, a novel approach to relaxing this assumption and enabling the application of SFVI to a broader class of models with dependent local parameters. By capturing the dependencies among local parameters while still allowing for efficient and privacy-preserving learning, the SIGMA prior has the potential to significantly expand the scope and impact of FL in various domains.

2.2 Variational Autoencoders and PriorCVAE

2.2.1 Variational Autoencoders

Variational autoencoders (VAE, Kingma and Welling,, 2013; Rezende etÂ al.,, 2014) are a class of latent variable models that use variational approximation techniques to facilitate estimation of the latent spaceÂ ğ’›ğ’›\bm{z}. A VAE consists of a generative model,Â p~ğâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ’›)=p~ğâ€‹(ğœ½|ğ’›)â€‹p~â€‹(ğ’›)subscript~ğ‘ğğœ½ğ’›subscript~ğ‘ğconditionalğœ½ğ’›~ğ‘ğ’›\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{\theta},\bm{z})=\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{\theta}|\bm{z})\tilde{p}(\bm{z}), coupled with q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}), an amortised variational approximation ofÂ p~ğâ€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)subscript~ğ‘ğconditionalğ’›ğœ½\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}), the posterior distribution implied by the generative model. The use of the variational approximation facilitates learning the components of the VAE. We will refer to the generative model of the VAE simply as the generative model and useÂ p~~ğ‘\tilde{p} to distinguish this model from the true model that it is approximating.

The task of a VAE is to approximate some distribution pâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ‘ğœ½p(\bm{\theta}) using a latent variable representation p~ğâ€‹(ğœ½)=âˆ«p~ğâ€‹(ğœ½|ğ’›)â€‹p~â€‹(ğ’›)â€‹dâ€‹zsubscript~ğ‘ğğœ½subscript~ğ‘ğconditionalğœ½ğ’›~ğ‘ğ’›dğ‘§\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{\theta})=\int\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{\theta}|\bm{z})\tilde{p}(\bm{z})\text{d}z given by the chosen generative model. As in VI (see SectionÂ 2.1), the objective function employed by VAEs is the appropriate average ELBO,

â„’â€‹(ğ,ğ‹)=ğ”¼ğœ½âˆ¼pâ€‹ğ”¼ğ’›âˆ¼q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)â€‹[logâ¡p~ğâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ’›)âˆ’logâ¡q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)],â„’ğğ‹subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ½ğ‘subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ’›subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½delimited-[]subscript~ğ‘ğğœ½ğ’›subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½\mathcal{L}(\bm{\psi},\bm{\varphi})=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\theta}\sim p}\mathbb{E}_{\bm{z}\sim\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta})}[\log\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{\theta},\bm{z})-\log\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta})], (7)

where the first average is taken with respect to the true data generating process ğœ½âˆ¼pâ€‹(ğœ½)similar-toğœ½ğ‘ğœ½\bm{\theta}\sim p(\bm{\theta}). Note that replacing the approximation q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}) with the correct p~ğâ€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)subscript~ğ‘ğconditionalğ’›ğœ½\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}) simplifies (7) to â„’â€‹(ğ,ğ‹)=ğ”¼ğœ½âˆ¼pâ€‹[logâ¡p~ğâ€‹(ğœ½)]â„’ğğ‹subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ½ğ‘delimited-[]subscript~ğ‘ğğœ½\mathcal{L}(\bm{\psi},\bm{\varphi})=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\theta}\sim p}[\log\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{\theta})] which is the full objective function, as opposed to the ELBO. As such, we can view the variational posterior, q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}), as an approximation to avoid the difficulties in evaluating p~ğâ€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)subscript~ğ‘ğconditionalğ’›ğœ½\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}).

Deep latent Gaussian models (DLGMs, Rezende etÂ al.,, 2014) are a popular type of generative model commonly used within a VAE. The generative model for a single-layer DLGM consists of a latent variable ğ’›âˆ¼ğ’©pâ€‹(ğŸ,Ip)similar-toğ’›subscriptğ’©ğ‘0subscriptğ¼ğ‘\bm{z}\sim\mathcal{N}_{p}(\bm{0},I_{p}) and conditional variable ğœ½|ğ’›âˆ¼ğ’©dâ€‹(ğğâ€‹(ğ’›),ğˆğâ€‹(ğ’›))similar-toconditionalğœ½ğ’›subscriptğ’©ğ‘‘subscriptğğğ’›subscriptğˆğğ’›\bm{\theta}|\bm{z}\sim\mathcal{N}_{d}(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}),\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z})) where ğ’Ÿğ=(ğğ,logâ¡ğˆğ)subscriptğ’Ÿğsubscriptğğsubscriptğˆğ\mathcal{D}_{\bm{\psi}}=(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}},\log\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{\psi}}) are obtained via the joint output of a neural network termed the decoder, parameterized byÂ ğğ\bm{\psi}. The variational approximation q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½)subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}) is constructed from an encoder,Â â„°ğ‹=(ğğ‹,logâ¡ğˆğ‹)subscriptâ„°ğ‹subscriptğğ‹subscriptğˆğ‹\mathcal{E}_{\bm{\varphi}}=(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\varphi}},\log\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{\varphi}}) such that ğ’›|ğœ½âˆ¼ğ’©pâ€‹(ğğ‹â€‹(ğœ½),ğˆğ‹â€‹(ğœ½))similar-toconditionalğ’›ğœ½subscriptğ’©ğ‘subscriptğğ‹ğœ½subscriptğˆğ‹ğœ½\bm{z}|\bm{\theta}\sim\mathcal{N}_{p}(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{\theta}),\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{\theta})). The combination of using a decoder in the generative model and using an encoder to parameterize the variational approximation results in a probabilistic analog to the autoencoder (Tschannen etÂ al.,, 2018).

VAEs were originally designed to construct a generative model for finite observed data, say {xi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}. In this case, pâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ‘ğœ½p(\bm{\theta}) is an empirical distribution, pâ€‹(ğœ½)=âˆ‘i=1nÎ´xiâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ‘ğœ½superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ›¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœ½p(\bm{\theta})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\delta_{x_{i}}(\bm{\theta}), and the outer expectation of (7) becomes an empirical average over the data {xi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{x_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}. Estimation then typically involves stochastic gradient descent (SGD, Ruder,, 2017) to handle the inner expectation of (7). Mini-batching of the data (Hoffman etÂ al.,, 2013) is also frequently used and provides an unbiased estimate of the outer expectation of (7). VAEs can also be used when pâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ‘ğœ½p(\bm{\theta}) is a non-empirical distribution that can be sampled from (e.g. continuous). In this case, SGD is used to handle both expectations. We present this approach for the case of prior approximation next.

2.2.2 PriorVAE and PriorCVAE

PriorVAE (Semenova etÂ al.,, 2022) adopts a VAE approach to learn an approximate prior distribution, which can be used in place of the desired prior. Such an approximation aims to reduce the dimensionality or difficulty of an inferential task when the prior is the computational bottleneck because, for example, it is costly to evaluate. PriorVAE uses a decoder ğ’Ÿğ=(ğğ,logâ¡Î³)subscriptğ’Ÿğsubscriptğğğ›¾\mathcal{D}_{\bm{\psi}}=(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}},\log\gamma) with fixed variance Î³2superscriptğ›¾2\gamma^{2} and optimizes (7) using SGD with draws ğœ½âˆ¼pâ€‹(ğœ½)similar-toğœ½ğ‘ğœ½\bm{\theta}\sim p(\bm{\theta}) from the desired prior distribution.

The approximate prior is constructed from the VAE by takingÂ ğœ½=ğğâ€‹(ğ’›)ğœ½subscriptğğğ’›\bm{\theta}=\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}) withÂ ğ’›âˆ¼Npâ€‹(ğŸ,Ip)similar-toğ’›subscriptğ‘ğ‘0subscriptğ¼ğ‘\bm{z}\sim N_{p}(\bm{0},I_{p}), or more generally ğ’›âˆ¼p~â€‹(ğ’›)similar-toğ’›~ğ‘ğ’›\bm{z}\sim\tilde{p}(\bm{z}), where ğğâ€‹(ğ’›)subscriptğğğ’›\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}) is the mean output of the decoder. Using the approximate prior changes the posterior distribution from Ï€â€‹(ğœ½|ğ’™)âˆpâ€‹(ğ’™|ğœ½)â€‹pâ€‹(ğœ½)proportional-toğœ‹conditionalğœ½ğ’™ğ‘conditionalğ’™ğœ½ğ‘ğœ½\pi(\bm{\theta}|\bm{x})\propto p(\bm{x}|\bm{\theta})p(\bm{\theta}) over ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} to the approximate posterior Ï€~â€‹(ğ’›|ğ’™)âˆpâ€‹(ğ’™|ğğâ€‹(ğ’›))â€‹p~â€‹(ğ’›)proportional-to~ğœ‹conditionalğ’›ğ’™ğ‘conditionalğ’™subscriptğğğ’›~ğ‘ğ’›\tilde{\pi}(\bm{z}|\bm{x})\propto p(\bm{x}|\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}))\tilde{p}(\bm{z}) over ğ’›ğ’›\bm{z}. The ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} implied by the approximate posterior is recovered usingÂ ğœ½=ğğâ€‹(ğ’›)ğœ½subscriptğğğ’›\bm{\theta}=\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{z}). One can choose the dimension of the latent variables pâ‰ªdmuch-less-thanğ‘ğ‘‘p\ll d, ensuring that the effective dimension of the approximate posterior is much less than the original posterior. Large computational benefits during inference were observed by Semenova etÂ al., (2022), who motivate their work from this perspective.

PriorCVAE (Semenova etÂ al.,, 2023) extends PriorVAE to approximate conditional priors of the form pâ€‹(ğœ½,Ï•)=pâ€‹(ğœ½|Ï•)â€‹pâ€‹(Ï•)ğ‘ğœ½bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘conditionalğœ½bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘bold-italic-Ï•p(\bm{\theta},\bm{\phi})=p(\bm{\theta}|\bm{\phi})p(\bm{\phi}) whereÂ Ï•bold-italic-Ï•\bm{\phi} is a random variable that forms a hierarchy in the prior structure. Rather than approximating pâ€‹(ğœ½,Ï•)ğ‘ğœ½bold-italic-Ï•p(\bm{\theta},\bm{\phi}) entirely, PriorCVAE only approximates the conditional prior pâ€‹(ğœ½|Ï•)ğ‘conditionalğœ½bold-italic-Ï•p(\bm{\theta}|\bm{\phi}), thus retaining pâ€‹(Ï•)ğ‘bold-italic-Ï•p(\bm{\phi}) in both the original and approximate prior. With this extension, the ELBO (7) becomes

â„’â€‹(ğ,ğ‹)=ğ”¼(ğœ½,Ï•)âˆ¼pâ€‹ğ”¼ğ’›âˆ¼q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½,Ï•)â€‹[logâ¡p~ğâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ’›|Ï•)âˆ’logâ¡q~ğ‹â€‹(ğ’›|ğœ½,Ï•)].â„’ğğ‹subscriptğ”¼similar-toğœ½bold-italic-Ï•ğ‘subscriptğ”¼similar-toğ’›subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½bold-italic-Ï•delimited-[]subscript~ğ‘ğğœ½conditionalğ’›bold-italic-Ï•subscript~ğ‘ğ‹conditionalğ’›ğœ½bold-italic-Ï•\mathcal{L}(\bm{\psi},\bm{\varphi})=\mathbb{E}_{(\bm{\theta},\bm{\phi})\sim p}\mathbb{E}_{\bm{z}\sim\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta},\bm{\phi})}[\log\tilde{p}_{\bm{\psi}}(\bm{\theta},\bm{z}|\bm{\phi})-\log\tilde{q}_{\bm{\varphi}}(\bm{z}|\bm{\theta},\bm{\phi})]. (8)

For the remainder of the paper, we will only consider the conditional variant of VAEs. To illustrate the PriorCVAE approximation we present a toy Gaussian Process regression example in TableÂ 1.

In this example, kğ’™â€‹(Ï•)subscriptkğ’™italic-Ï•\mathrm{k}_{\bm{x}}(\phi) is some kernel function evaluated at points ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} for a given value of the length scale Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. The VAE is trained using prior draws from the true model. In this instance, the model approximation provided by PriorCVAE replaces the GP prior with a deterministic reconstruction of the GP given ğ’›ğ’›\bm{z} and Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, thus reducing the dimensionality of the inference task to be proportional to the dimensionality of ğ’›ğ’›\bm{z} rather than ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}. The latter of which scales with the number of observations in the case of a GP regression.

3 Structured Independence via Generative Model Approximations

In this section, we introduce the Structured Independence via Generative Model Approximation (SIGMA) prior. A SIGMA prior approximates the latent structure of a probabilistic model using a VAE with a generative model that satisfies desired conditional independence properties. We motivate the use of SIGMA priors FL scenarios where the prior structure of the desired model does not factorize over clients. We learn a SIGMA prior with the desired conditional independence and factorization properties, which replaces the original prior. The resulting approximate probabilistic model with the SIGMA prior is then amenable to use with existing FL algorithms, such as SFVI (SectionÂ 2.1).

3.1 SIGMA Prior

The SIGMA prior is a novel approach to approximate the hierarchical Bayesian model described by equations (1)-(2). It introduces J+1ğ½1J+1 latent variablesÂ ğ’›G,ğ’›Lsubscriptğ’›ğºsubscriptğ’›ğ¿\bm{z}_{G},\bm{z}_{L}, where ğ’›L=(ğ’›L1,â€¦,ğ’›Lj)subscriptğ’›ğ¿subscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿1â€¦subscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{z}_{L}=(\bm{z}_{L_{1}},\ldots,\bm{z}_{L_{j}}), and Jğ½J is the number of clients, to capture both the shared and client-specific variations in the local parameters ğœ½jsubscriptğœ½ğ‘—\bm{\theta}_{j}. The global latent variable ğ’›Gsubscriptğ’›ğº\bm{z}_{G} induces dependence across clients, while the local latent variables ğ’›Ljsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{z}_{L_{j}} drive the client-specific variations. We choose the hierarchical structure to enable the desired conditional independence properties across clients, facilitating the use of computationally efficient FL algorithms. The form of the generative model is

where Ï•âˆˆâ„dbold-italic-Ï•superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bm{\phi}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, ğ’›Gâˆˆâ„psubscriptğ’›ğºsuperscriptâ„ğ‘\bm{z}_{G}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}, ğ’›Ljâˆˆâ„pj,ğœ½jâˆˆâ„djformulae-sequencesubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptğœ½ğ‘—superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—\bm{z}_{L_{j}}\in\mathbb{R}^{p_{j}},\bm{\theta}_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{j}} forÂ jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J}ğ‘—1â€¦ğ½j\in\{1,\ldots,J\}, and Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0. The Jğ½J functions ğğLj,ğG:â„pj+p+dâ†’â„dj:subscriptğsubscriptğsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—subscriptğğºâ†’superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘ğ‘—ğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}_{L_{j}},\bm{\psi}_{G}}:\mathbb{R}^{p_{j}+p+d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d_{j}} are neural networks, with parameters ğLjsubscriptğsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{\psi}_{L_{j}} and ğGsubscriptğğº\bm{\psi}_{G} respectively, used to produce the decoder for the VAE.

This hierarchical structure aids high-dimensional learning by allowing each local decoder to focus on learning the local deviations from a shared global representation captured by the global decoder ğ’ˆğGsubscriptğ’ˆsubscriptğğº\bm{g}_{\bm{\psi}_{G}}. We provide the architecture details of the encoders and decoders used in the numerical experiments in Section A.

3.2 Approximation of the prior

We construct the SIGMA prior approximation from the estimated generative model and variational posterior of the VAE. In particular, we use

Ï•âˆ¼pâ€‹(Ï•),ğ’›Gâˆ¼p~â€‹(ğ’›G),ğ’›Ljâˆ¼ğ’©pjâ€‹(ğğ‹Ljâ€‹(ğ’›G,Ï•),ğˆğ‹Ljâ€‹(ğ’›G,Ï•)),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J},ğœ½jâˆ¼ğ’©djâ€‹(ğğLj,ğGâ€‹(ğ’›Lj,ğ’›G,Ï•),Î³â€‹Idj),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J},\begin{split}\bm{\phi}&\sim p(\bm{\phi}),\\ \bm{z}_{G}&\sim\tilde{p}(\bm{z}_{G}),\\ \bm{z}_{L_{j}}&\sim\mathcal{N}_{p_{j}}(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}}}(\bm{z}_{G},\bm{\phi}),\bm{\sigma}_{\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}}}(\bm{z}_{G},\bm{\phi})),\quad j\in\{1,\ldots,J\},\\ \bm{\theta}_{j}&\sim\mathcal{N}_{d_{j}}(\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}_{L_{j}},\bm{\psi}_{G}}(\bm{z}_{L_{j}},\bm{z}_{G},\bm{\phi}),\gamma I_{d_{j}}),\quad j\in\{1,\ldots,J\},\end{split} (12)

which is identical to the generative model (9), except that the distribution of each local latent variable ğ’›Ljsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{z}_{L_{j}} is replaced by its variational approximation. Using the variational approximation of ğ’›Ljsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{z}_{L_{j}} as the prior is a significant advantage of the SIGMA prior compared to methods like PriorCVAE, as it allows for incorporating the learned variational approximation into the approximate prior. The hierarchical structure of the SIGMA prior enables this replacement, as the variational approximations for the local latent variables are conditioned only on the global latent variable ğ’›Gsubscriptğ’›ğº\bm{z}_{G} and the global parameters Ï•bold-italic-Ï•\bm{\phi}, which are already part of the approximate prior specification.

The SIGMA prior offers significant benefits by incorporating learned variational approximations for the local latent variables, which represent the optimal density of the latent space for reconstructing draws of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}. These local latent variables capture important information about the structure and dependencies within ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}, enabling the SIGMA prior to effectively model and generate realistic samples, setting it apart from approaches like PriorVAE and PriorCVAE.

Model 1 shows pseudocode for a one-dimensional GP regression. Model 2 shows pseudocode for an approximation to Model 1 using a SIGMA prior, where the encoders and decoders are trained using prior draws from the length scale parameter Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and the random variables ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}, denoted in Model 1 as phi and theta respectively. The pseudocode closely resembles how models are defined in modern Python probabilistic programming languages such as Pyro (Bingham etÂ al.,, 2019), Numpyro (Phan etÂ al.,, 2019), and PyMC (Abril-Pla etÂ al.,, 2023). The function call deterministic is employed to define variables whose values are computed directly from other variables without any inherent randomness. The function call sample is used for drawing random variables from probability distributions, and the context plate represents a mechanism for indicating conditional independence across different subsets of random variables and data.

The SIGMA prior approximation enables the inference of the latent variables ğ’›G,ğ’›L1,â€¦,ğ’›LJsubscriptğ’›ğºsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿1â€¦subscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ½\bm{z}_{G},\bm{z}_{L_{1}},\ldots,\bm{z}_{L_{J}} instead of the original local parameters ğœ½1,â€¦,ğœ½Jsubscriptğœ½1â€¦subscriptğœ½ğ½\bm{\theta}_{1},\ldots,\bm{\theta}_{J}. Notably, the SIGMA prior ensures the required conditional independence: ğœ½^jâŸ‚âŸ‚ğœ½^kâˆ£ğ’›G,Ï•\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{j}\perp\!\!\!\perp\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{k}\mid\bm{z}_{G},\bm{\phi} for all pairs of clients jâ‰ kğ‘—ğ‘˜j\neq k. This property is useful in FL settings, as it allows each client to perform local updates independently without the need for sharing raw data, thereby facilitating efficient and privacy-preserving learning. Furthermore, this property enables the use of existing FL algorithms such as SFVI (Hassan etÂ al.,, 2023) or FedSOUL (Kotelevskii etÂ al.,, 2022), which rely on the assumption of conditional independence among local parameters given the global parameters.

4 Numerical Examples

This section presents two numerical experiments that showcase the effectiveness of the SIGMA prior in handling highly dependent priors with increasing dimensionality and numbers of clients. These experiments demonstrate the scalability and adaptability of our approach in various settings, ranging from simple one-dimensional examples to complex real-world spatial structures.

The first experiment establishes a baseline for the SIGMA priorâ€™s performance using a one-dimensional GP prior with p=100ğ‘100p=100 dimensions and J=3ğ½3J=3 clients. We provide qualitative assessments through visualizations, including the empirical covariance of the SIGMA prior compared to the covariance of the GP prior, reconstructed draws from the SIGMA prior, and comparison of estimates when using the SIGMA prior to construct an approximate model compared to the true underlying model that contains the GP prior. The second experiment demonstrates the SIGMA priorâ€™s ability to handle complex, real-world spatial structures by considering a prior structure with dimension p=2227ğ‘2227p=2227 and J=8ğ½8J=8 clients, motivated by the Australian geography. This experiment showcases the scalability of our approach to more significant and realistic problems.

Throughout these experiments, we employ stochastic variational inference implemented in the Pyro library (Bingham etÂ al.,, 2019) to train the VAE, with encoders and decoders constructed using PyTorch (Paszke etÂ al.,, 2019). For posterior estimation in the approximate model, we use the No-U-Turn sampler (NUTS, Hoffman etÂ al.,, 2014) algorithm in the first example, and mean-field variational inference in the second example. Both algorithms are implemented in the BlackJAX (Cabezas etÂ al.,, 2024) library.

To evaluate the performance of the SIGMA prior, we use a combination of qualitative and quantitative metrics tailored to each experiment. Experiment 1 focuses on visual assessments. In Experiment 2, we compare inference estimates from the approximate SIGMA prior model with MCMC estimates of the true model. Additionally, we propose a novel correction by viewing the approximate model created with the SIGMA prior as an auxiliary-variable model, emphasizing how the SIGMA prior enables similar parameter estimates using an FL algorithm compared to MCMC and VI results on the actual model.

The following subsections (Sections 4.1 and 4.2) present each experiment in detail, discussing the specific settings, results, and insights gained. Appendix A describes the architecture details of the VAE common to the two experiments.

4.1 One-dimensional Gaussian Process Regression

In our first example, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the SIGMA prior in approximating a one-dimensional GP regression. We generate training data by sampling from a GP with a radial basis function (RBF) kernel at 100 equidistant points ğ’™trainsubscriptğ’™train\bm{x}_{\text{train}} in the interval [0,1]01[0,1]. The data is divided among three clients based on the input values: client 1 receives data associated with ğ’™âˆˆ[0,0.34)ğ’™00.34\bm{x}\in[0,0.34), client 2 receives data associated with ğ’™âˆˆ[0.34,0.67)ğ’™0.340.67\bm{x}\in[0.34,0.67), and client 3 receives data associated with ğ’™âˆˆ[0.67,1.00]ğ’™0.671.00\bm{x}\in[0.67,1.00].

We generate 10,0001000010,000 draws from a GP prior with an RBF kernel with the lengthscale parameter varying uniformly between 0.20.20.2 and 111 and with variance fixed at 111. We train the SIGMA prior architecture for 20,0002000020,000 iterations using the Adam optimizer (Kingma and Ba,, 2014) with a learning rate of 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} in Pyro (Bingham etÂ al.,, 2019). The batch size in each iteration is 323232, and the dimension of the hidden layers used in the neural net architectures is 161616. The dimension of the global latent space ğ’›Gsubscriptğ’›ğº\bm{z}_{G} and each of the three local latent spaces ğ’›L1,ğ’›L2,ğ’›L3subscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿1subscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿2subscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿3\bm{z}_{L_{1}},\bm{z}_{L_{2}},\bm{z}_{L_{3}} were chosen to be 555 respectively, and the standard deviation of the decoder is set to Î³=0.5ğ›¾0.5\gamma=0.5.

We train the SIGMA prior and compare its empirical covariance with the actual RBF kernel. Figure 3 visualizes this comparison, demonstrating that the learned SIGMA prior closely approximates the actual covariance structure for varying values of the length scale parameter.

To further illustrate the SIGMA priorâ€™s ability to capture dependencies across clients, we generate 252525 prior draws from the fitted SIGMA prior (Figure 4). The red-vertical-dashed lines denote the boundaries between clients, and the smooth transitions across these boundaries demonstrate that the SIGMA prior has learned the underlying correlations in the data.

We now use the SIGMA approximation in an inferential model. We generate 15 random locations ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} in the interval [0,1]01[0,1] and observations ğ’š=sinâ¡(ğ’™)+0.2â‹…Ïµ,ğ’šğ’™â‹…0.2bold-italic-Ïµ\bm{y}=\sin(\bm{x})+0.2\cdot{\bm{\epsilon}}, where Ïµâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,1)similar-tobold-italic-Ïµğ’©01\bm{\epsilon}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1). Figure 5 shows the mean estimate (solid blue line) and 90% credible interval (shaded region) for the mean function using the SIGMA approximation, with the posterior estimated using the NUTS algorithm.

This example showcases the effectiveness of the SIGMA prior in approximating a one-dimensional GP regression while capturing dependencies across clients in a FL setting. The learned SIGMA prior closely approximates the covariance structure, generates prior draws that smoothly transition across client boundaries, and provides a reasonable estimate of the posterior mean.

4.2 Fitting Bayesian spatial models over the Australian geography

In this experiment, we aim to demonstrate the effectiveness of the SIGMA prior in approximating the spatial structure of the Australian geography, using a proper conditional autoregressive (PCAR) prior (see Appendix B) to model dependencies at the Statistical Area Level 2 (SA2). This experiment is motivated by the Australian Cancer Atlas (ACA, Duncan etÂ al.,, 2019), which produces estimates of cancer diagnoses, excess deaths, and risk factors across the Australian geography at the SA2 level. The ACA comprises over one hundred individual spatial and spatio-temporal models, each employing a form of a CAR prior to smooth estimates and to account for spatial dependence in the data. Integrating new data sources into the ACA poses challenges, as it requires establishing new data agreements across the Australian geography. The SIGMA prior offers a potential solution by enabling the approximation of complex spatial structures while facilitating efficient and privacy-preserving learning in a federated setting.

In this experiment, we consider J=8ğ½8J=8 clients representing Australiaâ€™s eight states and territories. The parameter vector ğœ½âˆˆâ„2221ğœ½superscriptâ„2221\bm{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{2221} is assigned a PCAR prior distribution, ğœ½|Ï•âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,Î£âˆ’1)similar-toconditionalğœ½italic-Ï•ğ’©0superscriptÎ£1\bm{\theta}|\phi\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{0},\mathrm{\Sigma}^{-1}), where Î£âˆˆâ„2221Ã—2221Î£superscriptâ„22212221\mathrm{\Sigma}\in\mathbb{R}^{2221\times 2221} is the precision matrix defined as Î£=Dâˆ’Ï•â€‹WÎ£Ditalic-Ï•W\mathrm{\Sigma}=\mathrm{D}-\phi\mathrm{W}, where WW\mathrm{W} is the adjacency matrix, with Wiâ€‹j=1subscriptWğ‘–ğ‘—1\mathrm{W}_{ij}=1 if observations iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j are neighbors and Wiâ€‹j=0subscriptWğ‘–ğ‘—0\mathrm{W}_{ij}=0 otherwise. The diagonal matrix DD\mathrm{D} captures the number of neighbors for each observation, with Diâ€‹isubscriptDğ‘–ğ‘–\mathrm{D}_{ii} representing the number of neighbors for observation iğ‘–i. The unknown parameter Ï•âˆˆ(0,1)italic-Ï•01\phi\in(0,1) is interpreted as a measure of the spatial smoothing between neighbors, with higher values indicating stronger spatial dependence.

We generate 10,0001000010,000 draws from the PCAR prior over the Australian geography, with Ï•italic-Ï•\phi varying uniformly between 00 and 111. We train the SIGMA prior architecture for 400,000400000400,000 iterations using the Adam optimizer (Kingma and Ba,, 2014) with a learning rate of 1â€‹eâˆ’41superscriptğ‘’41e^{-4} in Pyro (Bingham etÂ al.,, 2019). The batch size in each iteration is 128128128, and the dimension of the hidden layers used in the neural net architectures is 202420242024 for the decoders and the global encoder and 104810481048 for the local encoders. The dimension of the global latent space ğ’›Gsubscriptğ’›ğº\bm{z}_{G} is 100100100 and the dimension for each of the local latent spaces is 505050. The standard deviation of the decoder is set to Î³=0.03ğ›¾0.03\gamma=0.03.

Due to the SIGMA prior being a model approximation and assessing the performance of an approximate algorithm in VI, we chose to use a synthetic dataset for this example where the response is a draw from the PCAR prior over the Australian geography. The synthetic dataset was generated by sampling from the PCAR prior. The precision matrix Î£Î£\mathrm{\Sigma} was constructed using the adjacency matrix WW\mathrm{W} derived from the SA2-level spatial structure of Australia, ensuring that the synthetic data accurately reflects the complex spatial dependencies present in the real-world geography. By assessing the approximations of the SIGMA prior and VI against this synthetic dataset, we can effectively evaluate their performance in capturing the true data-generating process without the confounding effects of model misspecification or data quality issues.

We employ (NUTS, Hoffman etÂ al.,, 2014) and mean-field variational inference (MFVI) algorithms, both implemented in BlackJAX (Cabezas etÂ al.,, 2024), to estimate the posterior distribution of the model parameters. For NUTS, we run the sampler for 5,00050005,000 iterations using the default hyperparameters and summarize the results using the last 2,50025002,500 draws of the chain, discarding the first 2,50025002,500 iterations as warmup. For MFVI, we run the algorithm for 10,0001000010,000 iterations, utilizing the Adam optimizer (Kingma and Ba,, 2014) with a learning rate of 1â€‹eâˆ’31superscriptğ‘’31e^{-3}. We clip the gradients if their norm exceeds 1â€‹eâˆ’31superscriptğ‘’31e^{-3} to ensure stability.

4.2.1 True underlying model

To assess the effectiveness of the SIGMA prior in approximating complex spatial dependencies, we define a true underlying model that serves as the target for our approximation. The true model for this example is

logitÂ â€‹Ï•logitÂ italic-Ï•\displaystyle\text{logit }\phi âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,2),similar-toabsentğ’©02\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(0,2), (13)
ğœ½|Ï•conditionalğœ½italic-Ï•\displaystyle\bm{\theta}|\phi âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,(Dâˆ’Ï•â€‹W)âˆ’1),similar-toabsentğ’©0superscriptDitalic-Ï•W1\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}\big{(}\bm{0},(\mathrm{D}-\phi\mathrm{W})^{-1}\big{)}, (14)
ğ’š|ğœ½conditionalğ’šğœ½\displaystyle\bm{y}|\bm{\theta} âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğœ½,0.5).similar-toabsentğ’©ğœ½0.5\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{\theta},0.5). (15)

The spatial smoothing parameter Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is transformed using the logit function to ensure it remains within the valid range of (0, 1). The prior distribution for logitÂ â€‹Ï•logitÂ italic-Ï•\text{logit }\phi is a Gaussian distribution with mean 0 and variance 2, allowing for a wide range of possible values for Ï•italic-Ï•\phi.

The spatial random effects ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} are assigned a PCAR prior, conditional on Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. The precision matrix (Dâˆ’Ï•â€‹W)âˆ’1superscriptDitalic-Ï•W1(\mathrm{D}-\phi\mathrm{W})^{-1} captures the spatial dependence structure, where DD\mathrm{D} and WW\mathrm{W} are the diagonal matrix of neighbor counts and the adjacency matrix, respectively, as described in the previous section. The observed data ğ’šğ’š\bm{y} are modeled using a normal likelihood function, conditional on the spatial random effects ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}. The standard deviation of the likelihood function is set to 0.50.50.5, representing the assumed measurement error or uncertainty in the observations.

After training the SIGMA prior on prior draws from the true PCAR model across the Australian geography, we obtain the following approximation, which we refer to as the deterministic SIGMA prior model,

From here on, we refer to this form of the approximate model as the â€œdeterministic SIGMA prior modelâ€, as reconstructed estimates of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} are deterministic given the other unknown parameters. In this approximation, the global latent variable ğ’›Gsubscriptğ’›ğº\bm{z}_{G} captures the shared information across all regions, while the local latent variables ğ’›Ljsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{z}_{L_{j}} capture the client-specific information. The deterministic functions ğğ‹Ljsubscriptğsubscriptğ‹subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\varphi}_{L_{j}}} and ğˆÏ†Ljsubscriptğˆsubscriptğœ‘subscriptğ¿ğ‘—\bm{\sigma}_{\varphi_{L_{j}}} represent the encoder networks that map the global latent variable and the spatial smoothing parameter to the mean and standard deviation of the local latent variables, respectively. The decoder network ğğLj,ğGsubscriptğsubscriptğsubscriptğ¿ğ‘—subscriptğğº\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\psi}_{L_{j}},\bm{\psi}_{G}} maps the local and global latent variables, along with the spatial smoothing parameter, to the reconstructed estimates of the spatial random effects ğœ½^jsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘—\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{j}.

The plots on the left-hand side of Figure 6 show the difference between ğœ½^^ğœ½\hat{\bm{\theta}} and ğ’šğ’š\bm{y} for the deterministic SIGMA prior model fitted using MFVI. Compared to the same estimate from the true model using MFVI (top) and the true model using NUTS (bottom), we observe that the estimates of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} from the deterministic SIGMA prior model overfit to the data. This overfitting behavior can be attributed to lower variance in prior draws of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} in the deterministic SIGMA prior model relative to the true model. Figure 7 (left) further highlights this issue by showing that the difference in mean estimates of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} between the deterministic SIGMA prior model and MCMC estimates from the true model has much greater variance compared to the difference between the MCMC and VI estimates under the true model.

4.2.3 Auxiliary variable SIGMA prior model

Here, we propose an extension to the inferential model one would fit when using a model approximation with a SIGMA prior. The motivation of the extension is to reduce the tendencies of the approximate model to overfit to the observed data and to correct the narrow credible intervals. We note that these overfitting properties were observed and left as outstanding problems in both the PriorVAE and PriorCVAE papers, with overfitting appearing to a lesser extent in the PriorCVAE paper.

Our proposed extension is motivated by first considering the same generative scenario as PriorVAE, where we have random variables ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} that we want to approximate with an alternative generative model. In the works of PriorVAE, PriorCVAE, and this paper, at inference, we have treated ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} as deterministic given the added latent variables. Alternatively, we can consider treating ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} as a random variable, with mean given by the decoder and variance ğ‰2superscriptğ‰2\bm{\tau}^{2}. From this lens, the added latent variable can be viewed as an auxiliary variable, and we would end up conducting inference over both ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} and the latent variables. If we choose the generative model

ğ’›ğ’›\displaystyle\bm{z} âˆ¼ğ’©Pâ€‹(0,1),similar-toabsentsubscriptğ’©ğ‘ƒ01\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}_{P}(0,1),
ğœ½|ğ’›conditionalğœ½ğ’›\displaystyle\bm{\theta}|\bm{z} âˆ¼ğ’©Dâ€‹(ğğœ½+Wğœ½âŠ¤â€‹ğ’›,ğ‰2),similar-toabsentsubscriptğ’©ğ·subscriptğğœ½superscriptsubscriptWğœ½topğ’›superscriptğ‰2\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}_{D}\big{(}\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\theta}}+\mathrm{W}_{\bm{\theta}}^{\top}\bm{z},\bm{\tau}^{2}\big{)},

with unknown parameters ğğœ½,Wğœ½subscriptğğœ½subscriptWğœ½\bm{\mu}_{\bm{\theta}},\mathrm{W}_{\bm{\theta}}, and ğ‰ğ‰\bm{\tau}, we are fitting probabilistic PCA (PPCA, Tipping and Bishop,, 1999) to prior draws from pâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ‘ğœ½p(\bm{\theta}), where the maximum likelihood estimate for ğ‰2superscriptğ‰2\bm{\tau}^{2} is the average of the Dâˆ’Pğ·ğ‘ƒD-P smallest eigenvalues of the empirical covariance matrix of draws from pâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ‘ğœ½p(\bm{\theta}). If viewing from this perspective, then fitting a PPCA model to prior draws of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} and, at inference, jointly sampling from pâ€‹(ğœ½,ğ’›)=pâ€‹(ğœ½)â€‹pâ€‹(ğœ½|ğ’›)ğ‘ğœ½ğ’›ğ‘ğœ½ğ‘conditionalğœ½ğ’›p(\bm{\theta},\bm{z})=p(\bm{\theta})p(\bm{\theta}|\bm{z}) can be viewed as an approximate auxiliary variable method. If the dimension of ğ’›ğ’›\bm{z} is chosen such that P=Dğ‘ƒğ·P=D, then ğ‰2â†’0â†’superscriptğ‰20\bm{\tau}^{2}\rightarrow 0, and we essentially fit a deterministic location-scale transform to draws of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}.

As the decoder we use is not an affine transformation as in PPCA but a neural network, we do not get analytical estimates for the variance ğ‰2superscriptğ‰2\bm{\tau}^{2}. However, we offer a post-hoc correction. Under the true model, we can sample from the prior distributions to generate draws of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}, which we denote as ğœ½~Truesubscript~ğœ½True\tilde{\bm{\theta}}_{\text{True}}. We do the same for the deterministic SIGMA prior model and call these draws ğœ½~SIGMAsubscript~ğœ½SIGMA\tilde{\bm{\theta}}_{\text{SIGMA}}. We assume that ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} is Gaussian distributed, centred on the decoder estimates, with unknown variance ğ‰2superscriptğ‰2\bm{\tau}^{2}. We attempt to match the amount of prior variance using the SIGMA prior and the true model. Given our formulation, the variance is additive, i.e., Varâ€‹(ğœ½~True)=Varâ€‹(ğœ½~SIGMA)+ğ‰2Varsubscript~ğœ½TrueVarsubscript~ğœ½SIGMAsuperscriptğ‰2\text{Var}(\tilde{\bm{\theta}}_{\text{True}})=\text{Var}(\tilde{\bm{\theta}}_{\text{SIGMA}})+\bm{\tau}^{2}. This expression enables us to estimate ğ‰2superscriptğ‰2\bm{\tau}^{2} after fitting the VAE but before inference by taking prior draws from the two models and calculating ğ‰2=Varâ€‹(ğœ½~True)âˆ’Varâ€‹(ğœ½~SIGMA)superscriptğ‰2Varsubscript~ğœ½TrueVarsubscript~ğœ½SIGMA\bm{\tau}^{2}=\text{Var}(\tilde{\bm{\theta}}_{\text{True}})-\text{Var}(\tilde{\bm{\theta}}_{\text{SIGMA}}). As the estimator for ğ‰2superscriptğ‰2\bm{\tau}^{2} might not be positive, we clip the estimates to be between the range 0.010.010.01 and 100100100. For this example, 99.8%percent99.899.8\% of the elements of ğ‰2superscriptğ‰2\bm{\tau}^{2} did not require clipping.

We call this model the auxiliary variable SIGMA prior model and, for this example, define it as

ğ’›Gsubscriptğ’›ğº\displaystyle\bm{z}_{G} âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,1),similar-toabsentğ’©01\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1),

ğœ½^^ğœ½\displaystyle\hat{\bm{\theta}} =ğÏˆLj,ÏˆGâ€‹(ğ’›G,ğ’›Lj,Ï•),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J},formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptğsubscriptğœ“subscriptğ¿ğ‘—subscriptğœ“ğºsubscriptğ’›ğºsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—italic-Ï•ğ‘—1â€¦ğ½\displaystyle=\bm{\mu}_{\psi_{L_{j}},\psi_{G}}(\bm{z}_{G},\bm{z}_{L_{j}},\phi),\quad j\in\{1,\ldots,J\},
ğœ½|ğ’›G,ğ’›Lj,Ï•conditionalğœ½subscriptğ’›ğºsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—italic-Ï•\displaystyle\bm{\theta}|\bm{z}_{G},\bm{z}_{L_{j}},\phi âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğœ½^,ğ‰),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J},formulae-sequencesimilar-toabsentğ’©^ğœ½ğ‰ğ‘—1â€¦ğ½\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\hat{\bm{\theta}},\bm{\tau}),\quad j\in\{1,\ldots,J\},
ğ’šj|ğœ½conditionalsubscriptğ’šğ‘—ğœ½\displaystyle\bm{y}_{j}|\bm{\theta} âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğœ½,0.5),jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,J}.formulae-sequencesimilar-toabsentğ’©ğœ½0.5ğ‘—1â€¦ğ½\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{\theta},0.5),\quad j\in\{1,\ldots,J\}.

The addition of the conditional density of ğœ½|ğ’›G,ğ’›Lj,Ï•conditionalğœ½subscriptğ’›ğºsubscriptğ’›subscriptğ¿ğ‘—italic-Ï•\bm{\theta}|\bm{z}_{G},\bm{z}_{L_{j}},\phi does not introduce any additional dependencies between clients, as all the dependencies are already captured by estimating ğœ½^^ğœ½\hat{\bm{\theta}} through the learned SIGMA prior. Thus, including this density is straightforward from an FL perspective. While treating ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} as a random variable increases the dimensionality of the model, the computational cost remains manageable when using a variational inference algorithm with a mean-field assumption for the variational family of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta}.

Figure 6 (right-hand side) illustrates the difference between the mean estimate of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} and the observed data ğ’šğ’š\bm{y} for the auxiliary SIGMA prior model fitted using mean-field variational inference (MFVI). Comparing these estimates to those obtained from the true model using MFVI (top) and NUTS (bottom) reveals that the auxiliary variable SIGMA prior model achieves similar levels of smoothing with respect to the data. Notably, the auxiliary variable approach significantly reduces the overfitting observed in the estimates from the deterministic SIGMA prior model. Moreover, Figure 7 (right-hand side) demonstrates that the difference between the mean estimates of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} under the auxiliary variable SIGMA prior and the MCMC estimates under the true model is substantially smaller than the difference between the mean estimates of ğœ½ğœ½\bm{\theta} under the deterministic SIGMA prior and the MCMC estimates. This finding suggests that the auxiliary variable SIGMA prior model approximates the true posterior distribution more closely than the deterministic SIGMA prior model.

5 Conclusion

In this paper, we introduced the Structured Independence via deep Generative Model Approximation (SIGMA) prior, a novel approach to approximating the latent structure of probabilistic models while enforcing desired conditional independence properties. The SIGMA prior utilizes a hierarchical variational autoencoder (VAE) to capture dependencies in the original prior specification and induce conditional independence among subsets of variables. The key components of the hierarchical VAE include a global latent variable that captures shared information across all clients, local latent variables that capture client-specific information, and encoder and decoder networks that map between the latent space and the original parameter space. By carefully designing the architecture and training objective of the VAE, the SIGMA prior enables the approximation of complex prior distributions while maintaining the desired conditional independence structure.

The development of the SIGMA prior is motivated by the challenges of horizontal FL, where data is distributed across multiple clients, and direct access to data from other clients is prohibited. Existing FL algorithms, such as SFVI (Hassan etÂ al.,, 2023), assume independence between clients, limiting their applicability to scenarios where dependencies are present. The SIGMA prior addresses this limitation by approximating the prior distribution over client-specific parameters and inducing conditional independence between clients, enabling the use of existing FL algorithms while capturing dependencies between clients. This advancement is significant, as it allows for accurate inference and prediction in real-world applications where dependencies between clients are expected. We evaluated the performance of the SIGMA prior on a synthetic and real-world application, including a one-dimensional GP prior and a CAR prior for modeling spatial dependencies in cancer estimates across the Australian geography. Our experiments showed that the SIGMA prior effectively captures the dependencies in the original prior distributions and provides a close approximation to estimates from the actual model in the non-FL setting. These results highlight the potential of the SIGMA prior as a general-purpose tool for enabling FL with dependent data. The successful application of the SIGMA prior to the CAR prior across the Australian geography demonstrates the real-world impact of our approach. Spatial dependencies are prevalent in many fields, such as epidemiology, environmental sciences, and social sciences, where data is often collected at different spatial resolutions or administrative units. The SIGMA prior provides a principled way to model these dependencies in an FL setting, enabling collaboration between organizations or data custodians without compromising data privacy.

Despite the promising results, there are several limitations and avenues for future research. One avenue for potential extensions is to explore alternative generative models for the SIGMA prior, such as normalizing flows (Rezende and Mohamed,, 2015), generative adversarial networks (Goodfellow etÂ al.,, 2014), or denoising diffusion models (Song and Ermon,, 2019; Ho etÂ al.,, 2020; Kingma etÂ al.,, 2021). These models have shown promising results in capturing complex distributions and could improve the expressiveness and flexibility of the SIGMA prior. Additionally, the auxiliary variable SIGMA prior model introduced in this work offers a promising direction for future research. The auxiliary variable approach can reduce overfitting and improve the calibration of uncertainty estimates by treating the local parameters as random variables and introducing an additional conditional distribution. Further investigation into the theoretical properties and practical implications of the auxiliary variable SIGMA prior model could lead to more robust and reliable model approximations.

In conclusion, the SIGMA prior is a powerful and flexible tool for enabling FL with dependent data. By approximating the prior distribution and inducing conditional independence, the SIGMA prior allows using existing FL algorithms while capturing dependencies between clients. Our work opens up new possibilities for collaborative learning and privacy-preserving inference in various applications, from spatial modeling in healthcare and beyond. As FL continues to evolve, ideas surrounding the SIGMA prior could play an essential role in developing more expressive and accurate models that can leverage the full potential of decentralized data.

Appendix B Details for the proper CAR prior

The CAR prior captures the spatial dependence between neighboring regions by conditioning the value of a spatial random effect at a particular location on the values of its neighbors. In the proper CAR prior, the spatial random effects Ï•=(Ï•1,â€¦,Ï•n)âŠ¤bold-italic-Ï•superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•1â€¦subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›top\bm{\phi}=(\phi_{1},\ldots,\phi_{n})^{\top} are assumed to follow a multivariate normal distribution with a covariance matrix that depends on the neighborhood structure of the regions. The joint distribution of the proper CAR prior is given by:

Ï•âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğŸ,Ïƒ2â€‹(Dâˆ’Î±â€‹W)âˆ’1),similar-tobold-italic-Ï•ğ’©0superscriptğœ2superscriptDğ›¼W1\bm{\phi}\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{0},\sigma^{2}(\mathrm{D}-\alpha\mathrm{W})^{-1}),

where D=diagâ¡(m1,â€¦,mn)Ddiagsubscriptğ‘š1â€¦subscriptğ‘šğ‘›\mathrm{D}=\operatorname{diag}(m_{1},\ldots,m_{n}) is a diagonal matrix with the number of neighbors for each region, WW\mathrm{W} is the adjacency matrix of the neighborhood structure, Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1) is a spatial dependence parameter, and Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is a variance parameter. The conditional distributions for each spatial random effect given its neighbors are:

Ï•iâˆ£Ï•âˆ’iâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î±â€‹1miâ€‹âˆ‘jâˆ¼iÏ•j,Ïƒ2mi),similar-toconditionalsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–subscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ’©ğ›¼1subscriptğ‘šğ‘–subscriptsimilar-toğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘—superscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘šğ‘–\phi_{i}\mid\bm{\phi}_{-i}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\alpha\frac{1}{m_{i}}\sum_{j\sim i}\phi_{j},\frac{\sigma^{2}}{m_{i}}\right),

where Ï•âˆ’isubscriptbold-italic-Ï•ğ‘–\bm{\phi}_{-i} denotes all elements of Ï•bold-italic-Ï•\bm{\phi} except Ï•isubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–\phi_{i}, misubscriptğ‘šğ‘–m_{i} is the number of neighbors of region iğ‘–i, and jâˆ¼isimilar-toğ‘—ğ‘–j\sim i denotes that regions jğ‘—j and iğ‘–i are neighbors. The conditional mean of each random effect is a weighted average of its neighbors, with the weight determined by the spatial dependence parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha. The conditional variance is inversely proportional to the number of neighbors. The proper CAR prior is proper because Î±ğ›¼\alpha is strictly between 0 and 1. When Î±=1ğ›¼1\alpha=1, the proper CAR prior reduces to the intrinsic CAR (ICAR) prior, which is improper because the precision matrix (Dâˆ’W)DW(\mathrm{D}-\mathrm{W}) is singular.
